newsitem.title: POLAND: POLISH MINISTER DENIES RESIGNATION LINKED TO RUCH.
newsitem.headline: POLISH MINISTER DENIES RESIGNATION LINKED TO RUCH.

text.p: Polish deputy treasury minister Leszek Juchniewicz, whose removal from office last week prompted media speculation, said on Monday his resignation was not linked to any privatisation deal he had been negotiating.

Juchniewicz said in a statement he had sought since January to leave the post to return to work in the banking sector and this should not be linked to any deal including a long-negotiated sale of the Ruch SA newsstand chain.
"Because of various media speculation...I want to make clear that I offered my resignation some time ago," he said.
"Linking my resignation with the privatisation of Ruch or any other company is not justified," Juchniewicz said.

The privatisation of Ruch, Poland's largest newsstand chain, has sparked controversy as a bid from a Polish-French consortium led by France's Hachette Distribution Services has been challenged by a late offer by a Polish group.
The ministry signed an initial agreement with Hachette on Ruch's sale in December 1996 but Juchniewicz later said the ministry would consider another bid if it proved competitive.
A rival bid was filed by a consortium led by trading company Universal last week.
Treasury ministry spokesman Zbigniew Ostrowski said the ministry would present new information about the Ruch talks at a news conference later this week.
